Comment:
Speed is seductive, but unchecked, it's like accelerating a car with no brakes. In India's startup ecosystem, we have seen this play out vividly, unicorns like Byju's chased hyper-growth without solidifying core user trust, leading to spectacular stumbles, while patient builders like Zoho bootstrapped their way to sustainable dominance by iterating meticulously on customer feedback.
The real art lies in "strategic slowness" pausing not out of fear, but to build antifragile foundations. It's about thriving in chaos, not just surviving it.

Headline: Redefining Business Travel
Comment:
Some places where speed actually hurts
1. Scaling too quickly - I scaled to 150+ customers within 1st 3 months of launch in my 1st startup, and then it blew! Scaling without perfecting fulfilment is a sureshot route to failure...
2. Building many things - Identify what's going to be the core & go deep in that. It's a big temptation to do multiple things fast in order to capture various markets - totally destroys focus!
3. Hiring fast - 200% chances of disaster! Hire only when convinced of the value add, also more people is NOT equal to more work - in fact, it's the opposite.

So, move fast - no doubt, but do the following first
1. Nail down fulfilment & support
2. Build the core to 90% perfection
3. Keep the team super lean even if it means a few extra days
